abstract_summ: OBJECTIVE: To describe experience with high-frequency oscillatory ventilation (HFOV) in children with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) transitioned from conventional mechanical ventilation (CMV) due to refractory hypoxemia and to assess factors associated with survival and also compare outcomes of patients who were managed with early HFOV (within 24 h of intubation) vs. late HFOV.In view of the limited evidence for HFOV in PARDS and evidence demonstrating harm in adult patients with ARDS, we hypothesized that HFOV use compared to other modes of mechanical ventilation is associated with increased mortality in PARDS.The primary objective of this network meta-analysis is to summarize the evidence and compare the effect of noninvasive oxygenation strategies on mortality and need for invasive mechanical ventilation in patients with acute hypoxemic respiratory failure.SYSTEMATIC REVIEW REGISTRATION: PROSPERO CRD42019121755BACKGROUND: RESP score and PRESERVE score have been validated for veno-venous Extracorporeal Membrane Oxygenation in severe ARDS to assume individual mortality risk.DISCUSSION: This study will help to guide clinical decision-making when caring for adult patients with acute hypoxemic respiratory failure and improve our understanding of the limitations of the available literature assessing noninvasive oxygenation strategies in acute hypoxemic respiratory failure.
title_summ: The impact of high frequency oscillatory ventilation on mortality in paediatric acute respiratory distress syndromeUse of high frequency oscillatory ventilator in neonates with respiratory failure: the clinical practice in Taiwan and early multimodal outcome predictionNoninvasive oxygenation strategies in adult patients with acute respiratory failure: a protocol for a systematic review and network meta-analysisValidation of RESP and PRESERVE score for ARDS patients with pumpless extracorporeal lung assist (pECLA)Noninvasive ventilation for pediatric interfacility transports: a retrospective studyOutcomes of Severe PARDS on High-Frequency Oscillatory Ventilation – A Single Centre ExperienceA multidisciplinary quality improvement effort to reduce bronchopulmonary dysplasia incidenceProtocol for two-arm pragmatic cluster randomized hybrid implementation-effectiveness trial comparing two education strategies for improving the uptake of noninvasive ventilation in patients with severe COPD exacerbationEffect of a new respiratory care bundle on bronchopulmonary dysplasia in preterm neonatesProne positioning in severe ARDS requiring extracorporeal membrane oxygenation
title_abstract_phrases: SYSTEMATIC REVIEW REGISTRATION: PROSPERO CRD42019121755Validation of RESP and PRESERVE score for ARDS patients with pumpless extracorporeal lung assist (pECLA)BACKGROUND: RESP score and PRESERVE score have been validated for veno-venous Extracorporeal Membrane Oxygenation in severe ARDS to assume individual mortality risk.Noninvasive oxygenation strategies in adult patients with acute respiratory failure: a protocol for a systematic review and network meta-analysisBACKGROUND: Acute hypoxemic respiratory failure is one of the leading causes of intensive care unit admission and is associated with high mortality.Use of high frequency oscillatory ventilator in neonates with respiratory failure: the clinical practice in Taiwan and early multimodal outcome predictionHigh-frequency oscillatory ventilation (HFOV) can be a rescue for neonates with refractory respiratory failure or an early elective therapy for preterm infants with severe respiratory distress syndrome (RDS).Outcomes of Severe PARDS on High-Frequency Oscillatory Ventilation – A Single Centre ExperienceOBJECTIVE: To describe experience with high-frequency oscillatory ventilation (HFOV) in children with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) transitioned from conventional mechanical ventilation (CMV) due to refractory hypoxemia and to assess factors associated with survival and also compare outcomes of patients who were managed with early HFOV (within 24 h of intubation) vs. late HFOV.The primary objective of this network meta-analysis is to summarize the evidence and compare the effect of noninvasive oxygenation strategies on mortality and need for invasive mechanical ventilation in patients with acute hypoxemic respiratory failure.
